title: Ask HN: Why do people get things when they “give up.”?
text:
I recently found an extraordinary technical co-founder for my company, after years of trying every possible strategy. He's 100 times more creative, passionate, expert and an ideal fit for me personally and from a business perspective, a friend I've known for years and seemingly popped back up out of the blue after I stopped trying and was ready to give up on the whole thing.

I've heard this advice of "give up" and it comes for years.

Give up on trying to find love and then you get the partner Give up doing a million interviews and then you get the job Give up trying to cure your alcoholic and your partner decides to go to AA on their own

I'm assuming this has something to do with the principal of "non-attachment" or not putting out a vibe of neediness, but it's still curious to me. Wondering if there's more to it than that.

And is there any way to enforce this state? Seems pretty hard to give up on something as a means to get it, so there's an inherent paradox.

Ask HN: Best C.S. Master program for Cybersecurity?
text:
I am a long time reader of many hacker/cybersecurity blogs, magazines and listening to tons of Podcasts about that topic.

I have a Bachelors degree in Computer Science and been a SE for over 10 years. I figured: Why not get a formal education in this field to find jobs/switch careers?

Any recommendations from people who‘ve done it and/or can recommend a path? I would also like a to do a formal masters degree in that field!
